attractions.Title: Acropole
attractions.description: Colline sacrée devenue le plus grand ensemble architectural et artistique issu de la Grèce antique

attractions.Title: Agora
attractions.description: Ancien centre de la vie publique de la cité antique, au pied de l’Acropole

attractions.Title: Erechthéion
attractions.description: Le monument le plus complexe du rocher sacré, considéré par les Grecs comme l’endroit le plus sacré de l’Acropole

attractions.Title: Jardin national
attractions.description: Oasis de fraîcheur, débauche de plantes luxuriantes, avec jardin botanique et un minizoo

attractions.Title: Mont Lycabette
attractions.description: Quartier résidentiel et touristique du centre d’Athènes, qui offre une belle vue sur la mer et, le soir, sur Athènes illuminé

attractions.Title: Musée archéologique national
attractions.description: Collections cycladique, mycénienne, de sculptures (l'une des plus importantes collections au monde)... ; un joyau exposant près de 12 000 pièces

attractions.Title: Musée de l'Acropole
attractions.description: L’un des plus grands musées archéologiques de Grèce, musée des superlatifs, trapèze de verre de 25 000 m²

attractions.Title: Parlement (Place Syndagma)
attractions.description: Sur la place Syndagma (la Constitution, en grec), la grande place d’Athènes, le Parlement grec ; lesevzonesde la garde, ces populaires soldats

attractions.Title: Parthénon
attractions.description: Édifice religieux, monument d’une grande richesse sculpturale, qui contenait une statue chryséléphantine d'Athéna

attractions.Title: Quartier de Plaka
attractions.description: L’endroit le plus animé d’Athènes, aux tavernes et aux airs de petit village

attractions.Title: Akrópoli (Acropolis)
attractions.description: The show-stopping Acropolis (upper city) dominates both the city's skyline and any tourist's itinerary. Athens’ original settlement was founded on this rocky outcrop and it has seen modifications through the millennia. The site includes four sacred buildings, all from the Golden Age of Pericles (461-429BCE). The steep ascent to the summit leads to the Propylaea, a monumental entrance to the site in Ionic and Doric styles. The Temple of Athena Nike is to the left of the Propylaea; the original was demolished in 480 BCE by the Persians and a new temple was built over the remains. It was  damaged again by Turkish forces in the 17th century but was beautifully restored after the independence of Greece in 1834. The Parthenon is the largest building on the Acropolis and an icon of Western civilisation. Built entirely from marble, it was intended as a sanctuary for the goddess Athena and housed a massive statue of her, long since lost to history. Despite the tourists, the perfect harmony of the structure is still awe-inspiring. The Erechtheion temple is a dual shrine to Athena and Poseidon-Erechtheus and was built on the site of the mythical battle between the two deities. The south side features a series of six support columns designed as maidens or caryatids.
attractions.Admission Fees: Yes. Free admission on 6 March (in memory of Melina Mercouri), 18 April (International Monuments Day), 18 May (International Museums Day), The last weekend of September annually (European Heritage Days), 28 October and every first Sunday from 01 November to 31 March.

attractions.Title: Ancient Agora of Athens
attractions.description: Now a jumble of monuments and ruins, in Athens' heyday, the Agora was the focus of city life, serving as a place of trade and as the city's political, administrative and cultural heart. Law courts, temples and public offices were all based in this area, where ordinary Athenians, stallholders and merchants mingled with officials, politicians and philosophers. Today, the site is dominated by the 5th-century BCE Hephaisteion (Temple of Haephaistos), one of Greece’s best-preserved ancient temples. The fascinating Museum of the Ancient Agora) contains an eccentric array of everyday artefacts found in the area. It is housed in the second-century BCE Stoa Attalou (Stoa of Attalos), which is thought to have been an early shopping arcade containing 42 separate shops.
attractions.Admission Fees: Yes. Free admission on 6 March (in memory of Melina Mercouri), 18 April (International Monuments Day), 18 May (International Museums Day), The last weekend of September annually (European Heritage Days), 28 October and every first Sunday from 01 November to 31 March.

attractions.Title: Ethnikó Archaiologikó Mouseío (National Archaeological Museum)
attractions.description: Housed in a late 19th-century building, the vast Archaeological Museum is undoubtedly the best museum in the country with one of the finest collections of ancient and classical Greek artefacts in the world. Fascinating pieces include the Mycenaean Art Collection, featuring hordes of finely crafted gold work dating from between the 16th and 11th centuries BCE, and the Bronze Collection, including an imposing statue of Poseidon or Zeus (no one is sure which) from 460BCE.
attractions.Opening times: From 01 Nov to 06 Jan: Mon 1300-2000 and Tue-Sun 0900-1600; from 07 Jan to 28 Feb: Mon 1300-2000 and Tue-Sun 0900-1600; from 1 Mar to 31 Mar: Tue 1300-2000 and Wed-Mon 0830-1600; from 01 Apr to 31 Oct: Tue 1300-2000 and Wed-Mon 0830-2000

attractions.Title: Néo Mouseío Akrópolis (New Acropolis Museum)
attractions.description: This impressive ultra-modern glass-and-concrete structure showcases priceless ancient statues and artefacts from the Acropolis site. The star exhibit is the marble frieze that once ran around the top of the Parthenon – although almost half the pieces are in London. Greeks hope it will persuade the British Museum in London to return those pieces - the controversial Parthenon Marbles, seized by Lord Elgin in 1799.
attractions.Opening times: Mon 0800-1600, Tue-Thu and Sat-Sun 0800-2000, Fri 0800-2200 (Apr-Oct); Mon-Thu 0900-1700, Fri 0900-2200, Sat-Sun 0900-2000 (Nov-Mar).

attractions.Title: Olympieion (Temple of Olympian Zeus)
attractions.description: Dedicated to Zeus, this was one of largest temples in the ancient world. Building work began in 6th century BCE, but was only completed around 640 years later in 2nd century CE under the Roman Emperor Hadrian. An earthquake damaged it during the medieval period, and much of the stone was subsequently carried away for use on other buildings. Today, 16 of the original 104 marble columns survive.

attractions.Title: Mouseío Benaki (Benaki Museum)
attractions.description: The museum houses the vast private collection of Antonis Benakis, the son of a wealthy Greek from Alexandria, Egypt. Displayed in a neo-classical mansion, the collection traces the development of Greek art, from the Stone Age up to the 20th century, with jewellery, ceramics, paintings, sculptures, furniture and costumes laid out diachronically. Highlights include the Thessaly Treasure (a stash of second century BCE gold jewellery) and two of El Greco’s early religious-themed oil paintings.

attractions.Title: Mouseío Kykladikís Téchnis (Museum of Cycladic Art)
attractions.description: The museum houses the spectacular private collection of Nicholas P Goulandris. Beautiful exhibits from the Cycladic civilisation (3,000-2,000BCE) form the focus of the collection. They include marble female figurines, thought to have been fertility symbols, which were inspirations for artists like Picasso and Modigliani, and decorated clay vases, placed in graves as votive offerings. Other artefacts span the pre-Minoan Bronze Age and the post-Mycenaen age up to 700BCE.

attractions.Title: Panathinaiko Stádio (Panathenaic Stadium)
attractions.description: This elegant white marble stadium was rebuilt for the first of the modern-day Olympic Games in 1896. It is a reconstruction of the ruins of a 6th-century BCE stadium that originally stood on the same site, and which was also used by the Romans. It should not be confused with the modern Olympic Stadium in the north of the city at Maroussi that formed the centre stage of the 2004 Olympics, though it was used for archery and the finish line of the Marathon.

attractions.Title: Théatro Dionysou (Theatre of Dionysus)
attractions.description: On the southern slopes of the Acropolis Hill, the Theatre of Dionysus was home to the original performances of the tragedies of Aeschylus, Sophocles and Euripedes and the comedies of Aristophanes. This stone auditorium, from the 4th century BCE, held 17,000 spectators and the ruins remain one of the most atmospheric of Athens' ancient sites.

attractions.Title: Roman Agora and Tower of the Winds

michelin.name: GB Roof Garden
michelin.address: 1A Vasileos Georgiou A street, Athènes, 105 64, Grèce
michelin.description: If you’re on the lookout for a restaurant that is a little bit special, this could be an excellent option on the 8th floor of the Hotel Grande Bretagne, thanks to its elegant setting and superb picture-postcard views of the Acropolis from both the delightful terrace and dining room. Despite not being overly extensive, the Mediterranean-inspired à la carte focuses specifically on fresh seasonal ingredients, with a special emphasis on Italian cooking, including a small section dedicated to pasta and risotto.

michelin.name: Tudor Hall
michelin.description: If the idea of having lunch or dinner on the elegant rooftop of a hotel, with piano music in the background and the eternal Acropolis as a backdrop sounds appealing, then Tudor Hall is definitely the place, especially for a romantic candlelit supper – but make sure you book a table in advance. Here, on the 7th floor of the King George Hotel, next to the central Syntagma Square, chef Asterios Koustoudis (who is also executive chef of the adjacent Hotel Grande Bretagne, home to the GB Roof Garden restaurant) showcases his contemporary take on Greek cuisine that is built around a concise à la carte and one tasting menu. The end result is a superb mix of slick service, sommelier recommendations and meticulous cuisine featuring delicious dishes that are surprisingly technical and pleasing on the eye. Make sure you try the superb cod.

michelin.name: Ovio
michelin.description: Run by celebrity chef Panos Ioannidis, this restaurant is, without doubt, an excellent choice for those exploring the busy streets of central Athens. In this spacious setting, divided into three dining areas (one on the ground floor, a few tables upstairs, plus a pleasant terrace) the chef offers a menu based around Italian cuisine. This includes homemade pastas, such as the delicious Gnocchi with a velvety sauce, diced pear, grated walnuts and finished with gorgonzola in two textures. These are complemented by meat dishes and pizzas cooked in the wood-fired oven, plus an extensive selection of Italian wines and a balcony where guests can savour an array of impressive cocktails.

michelin.name: Nolan
michelin.description: A contemporary bistro in the centre of the city, just a few steps from the busy Syntagma Square. The chef at the helm here (his father is Greek, his mother Japanese), creates contemporary Greek-focused cooking with plenty of Asian influences, and enticing dishes that are fresh, colourful and perfect for sharing. Next door is a separate space called “Sweet Nolan”, a pastry shop that complements the Nolan brand’s other ventures. In the summer months, the restaurant moves to Mykonos, with the whole team, and stays there from July to mid-September.

michelin.name: Aneton
michelin.description: Aneton moved from its previous location in Maroussi to this stylish, two-floored restaurant in the heart of the city, bringing with it its vibrant, eye-catching cooking. Lunch is light, with dinner providing the most interesting options, and the seasons lead the way. Service is friendly and engaging.

michelin.name: Okio
michelin.description: Okio comes with a cool atmosphere and a laid-back vibe; order a cocktail and settle in to enjoy the experience. The chefs add touches of originality to traditional Mediterranean recipes to create vibrant, interesting dishes which feature some bold Asian flavours; fish and shellfish feature highly.

michelin.name: The Zillers
michelin.description: This restaurant occupies the former family home of the German architect Ernst Zillers, who came to Athens to design some of its public buildings, fell in love with the city and remained here for the rest of his life. The building, which is situated next to the Greek Orthodox cathedral and has now been converted into a hotel (Zillers Boutique Hotel), boasts a rooftop terrace and multi-purpose Roof Garden with fine view of the cathedral and the Acropolis. During the day it serves light meals and snacks, but in the evening chef Vasilis Roussos and his team spring into action here! He offers two tasting menus: Synecdoche and Synthesis, both with creative dishes of traditional Greek influence and touches of international flavour. One standout dish was the Prawn Valley, a refreshing combination of raw prawns with a delicate tomato sauce, bergamot and kumquat that will definitely leave a lasting memory. The wine list also features a variety of Greek options to pair with your meal.

michelin.name: Dolli's
michelin.description: If the thought of enjoying a pleasant meal with an idyllic view appeals to you, then this could be the place. This restaurant is located on the fifth floor of the luxury The Dolli at Acropolis hotel, a historic mansion that has been completely remodelled and boasts picture-postcard views of the Acropolis. The menu here is a combination of Mediterranean cuisine with Asian options prepared by a chef who conjures up dishes within full view of guests in the dining room. Precise and meticulously presented, his dishes are always based around top-quality seasonal ingredients. The gourmet experience is more extensive in the evening and is complemented by the extensive array of wines, including labels from leading wine estates as well as artisanal vineyards.

michelin.name: Fine Mess Smokehouse
michelin.description: If you’re a fan of smokehouse-style dishes teeming with flavour which take the American barbecue concept to another level, you’ll want to add this eatery to your list, as you won’t find anything remotely similar anywhere else in the city. In this informal restaurant, the only dining option is the à la carte, which features an impressive array of dishes for sharing as well as others that showcase its “Low & Slow” barbecue process. Head chef Elena Kaperda is also the face of the “Lick the Spoon” project – a unique patisserie workshop.

michelin.name: SENSE
michelin.description: Located on the 7th floor of the AthensWas Hotel, SENSE boasts a stunning panoramic terrace with truly spectacular views of the Acropolis at sunset. The cuisine is centred around two tasting menus plus an additional vegetarian option, on which the innovative dishes are a fusion of international cooking and authentic Greek flavours, with plenty of creative detail as an added touch. Many of the aromatic herbs used in the dishes here are grown on the roof terrace.

michelin.name: Akra
michelin.description: A unique and special experience in which the chef does the cooking next to your table or at the wood-fired grill in front of you while you are seated at the counter. In addition, there’s also a bakery at the front of the establishment offering delicacies baked in ovens distributed around the room, that dispense their enticing aromas to add to the sensorial experience. Renowned chefs Giannis Loukakis and Spiros Pediaditakis run this small space in the charming Pangrati district of the city, where the young and relaxed vibe provides the backdrop for uncomplicated cuisine that is nevertheless full of personality and prepared with fresh, seasonal ingredients. The menu is refreshed every day, with dishes superbly cooked in the wood-fired oven taking centre stage.

michelin.name: Linou Soumpasis k sia
michelin.description: A casual and contemporary “new-age taverna” in the central Psiri district of the city where it occupies a former candle shop (whose products are still sold here to this day). Greek cooking is based around unpretentious yet delicious dishes that always showcase the restaurant’s commitment to organic ingredients.

michelin.name: Soil
michelin.description: There are few restaurants that are able to convey a connection between food, nature and a love for their country, but here chef Tasos Mantis manages to express his full passion for all three through his cooking. The experience starts with a presentation of some of the ingredients that will be used in your dishes, many are sourced from the garden overseen by the chef’s father. At Soil, the stars of the show are the vegetables, and above all the aromatic herbs, which are showcased on a single tasting menu that transmits originality, creativity and, first and foremost, quality. Located just a few steps from the Panathenaic stadium (the setting for the first Olympic Games of the modern era), occupies a house with a romantic patio shaded by orange and lemon trees. It also features a chef’s table, enabling guests to interact with the chef at close quarters as he prepares his dishes. An excellent selection of wines and a highly original non-alcoholic drinks pairing option adds to the appeal.

michelin.name: Makris Athens
michelin.description: Located at the foot of the Parthenon, this restaurant comes as something of a surprise for various reasons. Firstly, for the stunning view from its terrace; secondly, for its setting, in a historic building that was once the country’s first inn, with a decor that ensures a unique experience enabling guests to view its historic vestiges through the glass floor in the dining room; and, lastly, its cuisine, the main attraction, which comes courtesy of chef Patron Petros Dimas and which showcases the country’s gastronomic heritage through dishes that are creative and impeccable technique. The majority of the ingredients used are sourced from the restaurant’s own farm or from local producers and provide the basis for three tasting menus: Genesis, Utopia and the vegetarian Physis Vegan (the latter requiring pre-ordering). Guests can also explore the impressive wine list, home to a selection of 300 labels, including Greek and international options, plus interesting cocktail pairings.

michelin.name: Esthiō
michelin.description: This restaurant, the name of which translates as “eat and treat” in Ancient Greek, occupies a charming neo-Classical building dating back to 1931 close to the heart of the city. Here, Albanian-born chef Elvi Dimitris Zyba curates Balkan-inspired cuisine which offers a fusion between different cultures and combines the traditional with the contemporary. His cooking takes its inspiration from recipes that his mother used to prepare when he was a child to which he adds a more sophisticated and refined touch. Examples include the traditional “Giaourtotavas”, made with lamb sweetbreads, yoghurt and rice, and various seafood-based options, such as the Octopus stew, wrapped in handmade filo pastry with a sublime salmon roe cream. Desserts also have a Balkan touch, such as the Grape juice cream served with grape must cookies.

michelin.name: Annie Fine Cooking
michelin.description: This attractive neighbourhood restaurant, located along a tranquil tree-lined street away from the busy tourist heart of the city, boasts an everyday, informal ambience, along with a simple pavement terrace and striking touches of color in the dining room, with its open kitchen. It’s mainly local clientele flock here to enjoy dishes from the concise à la carte that are an updated take on Greek recipes and based around fresh, seasonal and locally sourced ingredients that showcase the country’s cuisine to the full.

michelin.name: Spondi
michelin.description: In this elegant restaurant close to a busy square behind the ancient Panathenaic Stadium, enjoy highly professional service, attractive vaulted dining rooms, and two Mediterranean-inspired terraces perfect for alfresco dining and a romantic candlelit supper. The cooking here is centred around elaborate and highly visual contemporary French cuisine that is showcased via an array of à la carte dishes as well as on an enticing “Discovery” tasting menu. Seasonal produce is very much to the fore here, although some ever-popular ingredients (crab, langoustine, lamb, chocolate etc) feature all year round. Particularly friendly and attentive service is a constant here!

michelin.name: Simul
michelin.description: Personality, irreverence, risk, youthfulness, technique and quality are the words that spring to mind when we think of Simul, a restaurant that is always focused on cuisine prepared “in-situ” with the very best seasonal ingredients. In the informal dining room, chef Nikos Thomas (perhaps better known for his appearances on MasterChef) offers his guests a choice between a continually evolving and creative à la carte and an impressive tasting menu.

michelin.name: Vezené
michelin.description: If you’re a fan of wood-fired cuisine, we recommend a visit to Vezené (located next to the Evangelismos metro station), a bistro-style restaurant with plenty of elegant decorative touches and an impressive glass porch. The menu is based around traditional Greek cuisine, in which fire plays a key role and via which the majority of the ingredients are prepared, endowing dishes with their unique flavour. It also includes various types of seafood sourced from local producers, as well as aged meats and impressive pastas. At the weekend, the generously portioned Sunday roast is available, which can be enjoyed with all the family, along with the restaurant’s famous signature dessert and a real must: Ari's Deal Closer!

michelin.name: Pharaoh
michelin.description: This restaurant boasts a concept that takes guests back in time thanks to its focus on the flavours of bygone days. At Pharaoh you won’t find modern cookers as every dish here is cooked using wood or charcoal as in olden days, endowing everything with a sense of simplicity and authenticity. The decor is a show in itself, with its combination of modern and industrial styles, open-view kitchen, plus a spacious balcony on which to enjoy your meal. Chef Manolis Papoutsakis’ cooking revisits Greece’s culinary traditions, but with a contemporary touch, as witnessed in dishes such as Tarama, Dolmadakia, Papoutsakia and Galaktoboureko. In the evening, a DJ adds to the atmosphere with music played on vinyl discs, so if you don’t want to miss out make sure you book in advance.

michelin.name: Gallina
michelin.description: A fine-dining restaurant with a focus not just on the quality of the cuisine but also on a genuine connection between art and gastronomy. Here, chef Pavlos Kiriakis combines French and Greek culinary traditions in dishes that showcase fish and seafood in particular. This harmonious experience extends beyond the boundaries of food thanks to the team of mixologists who create sophisticated cocktails, each one of which is named in honour of a mythological character. In addition, the impressive wine list boasts over 800 labels from different countries. In this vibrant ambience, with its elegant marble tables and a completely open-view kitchen, it is possible to sit in front of the latter to watch the chefs in full action. The floor upstairs is available for a more exclusive and intimate dining experience.

michelin.name: see|ds
michelin.description: A restaurant with plenty of personality located in a residential district of the city and which takes its name from the combinations of the word “see” and the initials of young chef Dimos Samouraki to create “Seeds”. The simple, modern cuisine, centred around locally sourced seasonal ingredients and a minimalist aesthetic, is showcased on two tasting menus(Short Talk and Long Story)that show French culinary influence and vary only in their number of courses. In addition, an interesting vegan option is also available. For those who prefer more exclusivity, the floor upstairs has a loft with an elegant dining space for 10 guests, where they can enjoy a more personalised experience seated next to the superb wine cellar.

michelin.name: Merceri
michelin.description: This welcoming bistro, close to the Herakleidon Museum is run by two chefs with experience gained at luxury hotels on the island of Santorini. Here, they showcase their talents through contemporary dishes with an international flavour, but which are based around typical Greek recipes. The offer is available à la carte or in a tasting menu, with wine pairing options.

michelin.name: Hytra
michelin.description: If you’re looking for a restaurant with plenty of innate charm, this could be the perfect option for you. Hytra is located inside the lush garden of Megaron Music hall, in a modern building that blends the fine aspects of contemporary design, the breathtaking view of Athens and the Athenian sky. Housing a balcony, a unique dining experience is offered under the stars and a warm, atmospheric inside dining area where guests can enjoy memorable dining experiences. The contemporary-style Greek cuisine on offer here, featuring fine textures and meticulous presentation, is based around Greek ingredients and herbs grown in the restaurant’s own kitchen garden, all of which are very clearly evident in its sauces, creams, seasonings, and even its cocktails. Choose between the à la carte and tree enticing tasting menus, one of which (Think Green) is vegetarian.

michelin.name: CTC Urban Gastronomy
michelin.description: If a dining experience under the stars appeals to you, this highly-sought-after restaurant, particularly during the summer months, will definitely fit the bill thanks to its charming urban terrace dotted with verdant trees and shrubs. Nor will the interior disappoint, with an elegant dining room decorated in soft colours and boasting a sophisticated ambience and subdued lighting. Here, chef Alexandros Tsiotinis, ably supported by his team, champions modern Mediterranean cuisine that is characterised by dishes that are meticulously prepared and extremely creative. More often than not based around classic dishes, including some from abroad, these are showcased in options Such as sea bass ceviche, Pesto calamari and a reinterpreted version of Tarte tatin. The surprise 11-course tasting menu is gradually revealed by serving staff as if they are unveiling a secret. You can also choose some excellent wine pairings to accompany you on this gastronomic journey!

michelin.name: Aleria
michelin.description: Time seems to have stood still in this beautiful restaurant occupying a neo-Classical residence from the mid 1800s, where the delightful patio, contemporary decorative features and 19C spirit come as a pleasant surprise. Here, the focus is on updated Greek cuisine presented in two menus (both with 5- or 6-course options): one entitled Earth & Sea, the other, the vegetarian-based Garden & Nature.

michelin.name: Cerdo Negro 1985
michelin.description: This small taverna with a casual ambience, close to the Kerameikos archaeological site, is run in a relaxed fashion by two brothers who have combined their Greek heritage with a passion for Spanish cuisine. In this single-storey property with an attractive covered patio, they complement their varied à la carte of contemporary Mediterranean cooking (most dishes are cooked over a wood fire), with a six-course Taste of Cerdo Negro menu. Make sure you try the homemade bread and the “Welcome to Cerdo Negro” starter.

michelin.name: Hervé
michelin.description: Hervé’s three co-owners are heavily involved in the smooth running of this modern restaurant, situated a little way from the centre but well connected thanks to its location next to the Petralona metro stop. Herve Pronzato is the French-born executive chef who has lent his name to the business, ably assisted by Grigoris Kikis (a young Greek chef who is constantly seeking excellence in his cooking) and George Efthimopoulos (an expert in hospitality and the restaurant’s general manager). One of the special features of this young, informal eatery is the elegant French-style yet Japanese-inspired counter where guests can watch the chefs at work (the latter serve dishes personally and are happy to explain their preparation in detail). The cuisine is centred around a single tasting menu featuring fusion dishes influenced by French, Asian and Italian cooking. You’ll need to book ahead, and when you do you’ll receive a digital code that will let you through the front door!

michelin.name: Jerár
michelin.description: Although located away from the tourist heart of the city, Jerár is winning new fans thanks to the cuisine on offer here. In this spacious and informal restaurant with a kitchen that opens out on to the dining room, chef Charis Nikolouzos showcases internationally inspired cooking that combines Greek roots (thanks to his connections with small-scale producers who supply him with his fresh ingredients) and French and Italian culinary detail. On the à la carte, featuring abundant dishes made for sharing, we particularly liked the Cacio e Pepe with “Mikrolimano Shrimp”.

michelin.name: VERi TABLE
michelin.description: A pleasant French-style bistro away from this delightful city’s main tourist haunts but which comes as a pleasant surprise thanks to its cuisine and friendly service. In this informal space, which is nonetheless elegantly decorated in dark tones and bathed in subdued lighting, savour dishes inspired by Provençal cuisine with a Mediterranean touch. True gourmet-lover and chef Aladin Parodi infuses his dishes with superb technical skill, with a focus on top-quality ingredients, as witnessed by the duck à l’orange – an absolute must here. The dining room is overseen by his wife, Christine Parodi, who devotes herself to providing exquisite service as well as managing the enticing wine cellar, featuring an extensive choice of French labels.

michelin.name: Delta
michelin.description: Delta is located inside the Stavros Niarchos Foundation Cultural Centre (SNFCC), an avant-garde complex that also houses the National Library of Greece and the Greek National Opera. This restaurant, on the fifth floor of the building, comes as a pleasant surprise thanks to the design of its dining spaces as well as other details such as the exclusively designed bronze bar, the dreamlike trees suspended from the ceiling, and the impressive sea views. Here, chefs George Papazacharias and Thanos Feskos, both of whom have been trained in some of Europe’s best restaurants, showcase their creative cuisine, which places sustainability at the heart of everything, hence the continual focus on the provenance of ingredients (from their own kitchen garden, locally sourced, responsible fishing etc). The striking cuisine here is focused on a single 12-course tasting menu called Omnivore, which can be savoured alongside an extensive selection of Greek and international wines plus a choice of champagnes.

michelin.name: Le Pavillon
michelin.description: (Temporarily closed for refurbishment) As soon as French-born chef Jean-Charles Métayer set eyes on this delightful whitewashed villa he is said to have fallen in love with it and immediately decided to set up a restaurant here. On his menus (one with 9 courses, the other 12), guests can savour contemporary cuisine that constantly interlinks French and Greek culinary influences, as both countries are key components of the chef’s unique career and life. The delicious and unusual “chocolate and mushroom textures” dessert definitely came as a surprise!

michelin.name: Botrini's
michelin.address: 24b Vasileos Georgiou B street, Athènes, 152 33, Grèce
michelin.description: When you’re thinking about a restaurant for a special occasion, the aim is to enjoy a unique experience. This is precisely the case at Botrini’s, where guests can embark upon a gastronomic journey that tells the chefs’ personal stories which unfold between stunning Greece (Corfu and Thessaly), and romantic Tuscany. Chef Ettore Botrini, who is at the helm of this restaurant, shows himself to be a superb ambassador for cuisine that is a fusion of both countries; while his right-hand man, chef Nikos Billis, dedicates himself to creating dishes that feature natural ingredients and have their roots in traditional cuisine. Occupying a former school on the outskirts of Athens, the restaurant’s interior features an elegant dining room with an open-view kitchen, the option of dining at the chef’s table or, in fine weather, in a pleasant outdoor space. The menu comes in two versions (Peripatos and Taksidi), both with the option of adding extra dishes to make the experience even more memorable.

michelin.name: Varoulko Seaside
michelin.description: If you’re looking for a restaurant with an authentic maritime flavour, this eatery overlooking the small yet attractive port of Mikrolimano will come as a pleasant surprise. Here, the relaxing ambience is in perfect harmony with superb views of the fishing boats moored out front. Traditionally, Piraeus is known as the port of Athens, hence the plethora of tavernas and restaurants specialising in fish and seafood located here. Varoulko Seaside follows the same influence, although chef Lefteris Lazarou takes his maritime cuisine to another level. The freshest ingredients are key to his cuisine which is based around the catch of the day (sea bass, red mullet, grouper, tuna, shrimp, prawns etc) and presented on an à la carte and two tasting menus.

michelin.name: Patio
michelin.description: Located in Vouliagmeni (an upmarket beach area on the shores of the Saronic Gulf just half an hour from Athens), this restaurant occupying a delightful internal patio in The Margi luxury hotel will come as a pleasant surprise. Here, in a verdant setting away from the centre of Athens, it is much easier to showcase the restaurant’s “From Farm to Fork” philosophy and concept. Chef Panagiotis Giakalis’ cuisine is presented on two tasting menus that champion modern Greek cooking of a high technical level, with particular emphasis on flavours from Greece and from the wider Mediterranean, wherever possible using ingredients (eggs, vegetables, fruit, olive oil, wine etc) sourced from their own estate. The covered side porch, the olive trees planted in huge pots, and the romantic candlelit ambience at night are particularly impressive, plus the hotel also owns a farm that guests can visit and enjoy a meal in beautiful natural surroundings.

michelin.name: Pelagos
michelin.description: If you’re keen to escape the hustle and bustle of Athens, why not consider a visit to the Four Seasons Astir Palace Hotel, a luxury resort located on an archipelago to the south of the Greek capital? At Pelagos, a restaurant that delights guests with its spacious sea-view terrace, enjoy Mediterranean cuisine with an Italian touch and classic French influence. In the kitchen, where talented chef Luca Piscazzi is at the helm, the cooking showcases a successful fusion of solid technique which extracts maximum benefit from local ingredients. The end result is highlighted on three tasting menus: Discovery, designed in the winter, when the chef explores the islands in search of ingredients and inspiration to bring life to the menu; Adventure, the most extensive, combining creations from the other two options; and the enticing The Best Of, that brings together superb dishes created by the chef during his career. We recommend booking a table on the veranda to enjoy the magical views.
